H0.text: when was the worlds first laptop computer introduced in the market and by whom. January 1973 by IBM

H1.text: when was the worlds first laptop computer introduced in the market and by whom. October 1981 by Osborne Computer Corporation

H2.text: when was the worlds first laptop computer introduced in the market and by whom. June 1975 by Xerox

H3.text: when was the worlds first laptop computer introduced in the market and by whom. September 1980

A4.text: The Osborne 1 is the first commercially successful portable computer, released on April 3, 1981 by Osborne Computer Corporation.

A5.text: In 1981, IBM released the IBM PC, which is significantly more powerful and expandable.

A6.text: The first Osborne 1 shipped in July 1981

A7.text: The company sold 11,000 Osborne 1s in the eight months after its July 1981 debut

A8.text: The first 'laptop-sized notebook computer' was the Epson HX-20, released in July 1982.

A9.text: The IBM 5100, the first commercially available portable computer, appeared in September 1975.

A10.text: The first commercially sold portable computer might be the 20-pound (9.1 kg) MCM/70, released 1974.

A11.text: MIT Suitcase Computer, constructed in 1975, was the first known microprocessor-based portable computer.

A12.text: The first 'laptop-sized notebook computer' was the Epson HX-20, invented (patented) by Suwa Seikosha's Yukio Yokozawa in July 1980.

A13.text: The first laptops using the flip form factor appeared in the early 1980s. The Dulmont Magnum was released in Australia in 1981–82, but was not marketed internationally until 1984–85.

A14.text: In 1975, the IBM 5100 could be fit into a transport case, making it a portable computer, but it weighed about 50 pounds.

A15.text: 1974 saw the introduction of what is considered by many to be the first true personal computer, the Altair 8800 created by Micro Instrumentation and Telemetry Systems (MITS).
